Award.AwardTitle: Creating and Implementing a Research-Infused Botanical Curriculum: Exploring Plants from Communities to Molecules

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biological Sciences (61). This plant-based life sciences curriculum project entails the design, implementation, and assessment of an innovative model for research-based pedagogy that allows all students to do original biological research across multiple levels of the biological hierarchy, from molecules to communities. The model introduces laboratory modules developed from ongoing undergraduate thesis work into core first-year courses, then incorporates undergraduate research projects vertically into biology curricula at the sophomore, junior, and senior levels. The modules supplement traditional instruction in basic plant science concepts (community ecology, taxonomy, physiology, and molecular population genetics), and facilitate development of experimental design and analysis skills. In addition, the modules are being designed to expose classroom researchers to several different facets of and approaches to studying the same problem during multiple time periods (lower- and upper-division courses), and to engender in them an appreciation of the scientific process. Rather than using only traditional one-on-one methods for mentoring undergraduate research, this approach provides first-hand, course-based research experiences for all biology students. The evaluation of the effectiveness of the modules at addressing goals for student learning incorporates use of several established and reliable instruments. The modules are designed to be flexible, allowing for adoption of the research-based pedagogy model at a variety of institutional types (including secondary schools, urban or rural universities, and schools with small or large student bodies), and are being shared through a website. This research-based pedagogy model also incorporates use of upper-level research students to mentor cohorts of underclassmen during laboratory exercises. The research students benefit by receiving invaluable instructional training; serving as mentors is giving them opportunities to become more knowledgeable and adept at communicating about their chosen research topics.

This project is being co-funded by funds from the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Emerging Frontiers Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For four years, faculty in UNCA’s Biology Department have been infusing authentic, plant-based research into our majors and non-majors curricula at the freshman, sophomore, and upper-division levels. We have designed laboratory modules based on current research projects at our university, an approach that has also been piloted at larger institutions (e.g., Kloser et al. 2011). This research-centered teaching approach helps faculty members balance conflicting demands on their time (Laursen et al. 2012), increases research productivity by allowing them to gather data while simultaneously immersing their classroom students in STEM research (Gardner et al. 2011), and creates meaningful synergy between teaching and research. Our model follows suggestions of Kloser et al. (2011), including the creation of a long-term community ecology database, structured facilitation of students’ hypothesis development (via faculty review of drafts), and reliance on institutional (faculty and student) research expertise. To date, over 300 classroom students have participated in these research projects, more than ten times the number of students that could be accommodated in traditional faculty-mentored research positions over the same four-year period.  

 

After taking courses with research-infused modules, students demonstrated measurable gains in their knowledge of plant transpiration (P = 0.0001), invasive species (P = 0.0001), and population genetics (P = 0.0109).  Students’ content knowledge of statistics, as assessed by test questions, did not increase significantly (P = 0.17), though scores on one of the two questions improved significantly (P = 0.0425).  However, students statistical skills did improve as evidenced by their improved ability to make statistically-valid hypotheses, (P = 0.0001), choose appropriate statistical analyses (P = 0.0003), and interpret statistical results (P = 0.0001).  Exposure to the revised curriculum increased students’ awareness of the importance of plants and botany (P = 0.0128), although interest in taking additional plant courses was unchanged from the start to the end of the course (P = 0.76).  However, students did report increased interest in participating in course-based research (P = 0.0001) or independent undergraduate research (P = 0.0403) after exposure to this research-infused curriculum. 

 

We have disseminated our research-based classroom modules within our university, where versions of them are utilized in the Biology Department (3 faculty members), Mathematics Department (1 faculty member), and Environmental Studies Department (1 faculty member). As a result, an additional 60 undergraduate students have been exposed to this hybrid teaching-research strategy. In addition, we have modified modules for our outreach efforts at three local secondary schools, where 75 students have now conducted classroom-based biological research, published research results.  We also have published data from our research modules in three peer-reviewed publications (Searels et al. 2013, Rossell et al. 2013, Horton et al. in press 2014), and produced a manuscript to further disseminate our modules (Ward et al., in press 2014).  Finally, we are working with colleagues from two other universities (Appalachian State University, Warren Wilson College) on a regional pedagogical consortium (CEREUS:  Consortium Exchanging Research Experiences for Undergraduate Students), focused on examining global change in the Southern Appalachians.
